titleStmt.title: Proverbs: from Urim -- an English prose translation

publicationStmt.distributor: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature

address.addrLine: The Oriental Institute, University of Oxford, Pusey Lane, Oxford OX1 2LE, UK, email etcsl@orinst.ox.ac.uk, http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk

seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

notesStmt.note: This file includes all manuscripts from Urim that consist of proverbs, except for UET 6/2 336 (= 6.1.28). So far as possible, proverbs duplicated in numbered collections are presented first, according to the number of the collection; the remaining proverbs are presented in decreasing order of manuscript size.

sourceDesc.p: Sources are listed in the header of the composite text

body.head: UET 6/2 291
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.1, 6.2.5: YBC 8713 ll. 1-2 Who can compare with justice? It creates life.
cf. 6.1.01.2, 6.2.5: YBC 8713 l. 3 Whenever wickedness may cause trouble, Utu will not be idle!
Let the standard that raises itself protect it like the heavens.

body.head: UET 6/2 265
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.6 That which bows down its neck in submission puts its breast forward in defiance.
cf. 6.1.03.23, 6.1.22: ll. 284-286, 6.2.5: IM 62823 Seg. A ll. 7-8 He who has silver is happy, he who has grain feels comfortable, but he who has livestock cannot sleep.
He who has nothing cannot let go of anything. When he enters &X;&X; no one gives him &X;&X;.

body.head: UET 6/2 239
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 320, UET 6/2 339 + UET 6/3 235 Seg. B l. 2, 6.1.01.9, 6.1.22: ll. 140-145 If bread is left over, the mongoose eats it. If I have bread left over, a stranger consumes it.

body.head: UET 6/2 320
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 239, UET 6/2 339 + UET 6/3 235 Seg. B l. 2, 6.1.01.9, 6.1.22: ll. 140-145 If bread is left over, the mongoose eats it. If I have bread left over, a stranger consumes it.

body.head: UET 6/2 261 and UET 6/2 262
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 339 + UET 6/3 235 Seg. B l. 3, 6.1.01.23, 4.14.1: l. 144 To be wealthy and demand more is an abomination to a god.

body.head: UET 6/2 221
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.65, 6.1.02.118 In the city with no dogs, the fox is boss.

body.head: UET 6/2 302
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.83, 6.1.26.a11, 6.2.5: YBC 8713 ll. 4-5 When a trustworthy boat is &X;&X; sailing, Utu seeks out a trustworthy harbour for it.

body.head: UET 6/2 284
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.126, 6.1.14.42, 6.1.19.c6, 6.1.22: l. 34 A plant sweeter than a husband, a plant sweeter than a child: may Ezina-Kusu a goddess of grain dwell in your house.

body.head: UET 6/2 210
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.128, 6.1.22: ll. 146-147, 6.1.23.9 In the sky there is the raven; on the ground there is the mongoose; in the desert there is the lion; my husband, where shall I go?

body.head: UET 6/2 306
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.142 Oh my sister, if there were no outdoor shrines, oh my mother, if there were no river, I would be dying of hunger.

body.head: UET 6/2 301
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.143 Thus my mother and my little sister act toward me: &X;&X; am I so deficient in judgment, that I should offer my cheek?

body.head: UET 6/2 334
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.170 She who says My expense is her girl friend. An interfering neighbour is the one with whom she quarrels.

body.head: UET 6/2 303
body.p: cf. 6.1.01.193-194 To be sick is all right, to be pregnant is painful; to be pregnant and sick is just too much.

body.head: UET 6/2 356
body.p: Give! -- Don't give! Don't let his hand touch it!
cf. 6.1.02.1, 6.1.07.1, 6.2.1: Ni 9824 Seg. A ll. 1-2 The course of its rituals was changed. Its cults were annihilated.
cf. 6.1.02.1, 6.1.07.1 Where there were ritual preparations, they were destroyed. You should not change the course of its rituals!
cf. 6.1.02.1 You should not destroy their cult! Where there were ritual preparations, you should not destroy them!

body.head: UET 6/2 292
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.2, 6.1.26.c10 Let me tell you about my fate: it is a disgrace. Let me tell you of my condition: it makes a man's mouth taste bitter.
That which matches my tears hurts my heart alike. It is said that rushes &X;&X; in the house.

body.head: UET 6/2 260
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.28, 6.1.02.34A, 6.1.22: l. 236 Moving about defeats poverty.
When liars enter by the city gate, in front of them there is a finger pointing at them, behind them there is a finger pointing at them.

body.head: UET 6/2 267
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.37, 6.1.11.146 You are a scribe and you don't know you own name? Shame on you!
cf. 6.1.02.54 A disgraced scribe becomes an incantation priest. A disgraced singer becomes a flute-player. A disgraced merchant becomes a con-man.

body.head: UET 6/2 268
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.38 If a scribe knows only a single line but his handwriting is good, he is indeed a scribe!
cf. UET 6/2 290, UET 6/3 452, 6.1.02.39 If a singer knows only a single song but he performs the melismas well, he is indeed a singer!

body.head: UET 6/2 290
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 268 ll. 3-4, UET 6/3 452, 6.1.02.39 If a singer knows only a single song but he performs the melismas well, he is indeed a singer!

body.head: UET 6/3 452
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 268 ll. 3-4, UET 6/2 290, 6.1.02.39-40 If a singer knows only a single song but he performs the melismas well. A scribe whose hand can follow dictation: he is indeed a scribe !

body.head: UET 6/2 269
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.49 How will a scribe who does not know Sumerian produce a translation?

body.head: UET 6/2 216
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.67 A fox urinated into the Tigris. I am causing the spring flood to rise, he said.

body.head: UET 6/2 214
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.68 He has not yet caught the fox, but he is making a neck-stock for it.

body.head: UET 6/3 31
body.p:
cf. 6.1.02.93, 6.1.07.81
A stranger's ox eats grass while my own lies hungry.
cf. 6.1.22: ll. 62-63, 6.1.22: l. 67, 5.6.1: l. 195, 5.6.1: l. 199 Good is in the hands. Evil is also in the hands. Wickedness does not feed a storehouse with interest.

body.head: UET 6/2 293
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.134 He who shaves his head gets more hair. And he who gathers the barley gains more and more grain.

body.head: UET 6/2 209
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.155, 6.1.28.24, 1.8.1.5: ll. 193-199 The palace is a forest, and the king is a lion; like Ninegala an epithet of Nungal he covers men with a huge battle-net.
&X;&X; genitals &X;&X;

body.head: UET 6/2 317
body.p: cf. 6.1.02.157, 6.1.14.20, 6.1.25.11 The palace cannot avoid the waste land. A barge cannot avoid straw. A freeborn man cannot avoid corvée work.

body.head: UET 6/2 244
body.p: cf. UET 6/3 80 l. 4, 6.1.02.c13, 6.2.2: MDP 27 206 l. 1 The head of the irsa&g; bird is the glory of the garden.
cf. UET 6/3 80 l. 6, 6.1.02.c14, 6.2.2: MDP 27 206 l. 3 The head of the francolin is the glory of the fields.
cf. UET 6/3 80 l. 5, 6.2.2: MDP 27 206 l. 2 The head of the frog is the glory of the &X;&X; well.

body.head: UET 6/2 335
body.p: cf. 6.1.03.39 You grind with the pestle like a fearful slave girl.
A happy ear is a happy god.

body.head: UET 6/2 382
body.p: cf. 6.1.03.77 I&c;kur splits the heavens, yet he does not split the waterskin.

body.head: UET 6/2 311
body.p: cf. 6.1.03.113 My mouth, every month I fill you, my mouth.

cf. 6.1.03.112, 6.1.03.114, 6.1.22: ll. 19-20, 6.1.22: ll. 21-25, 6.1.28.28 My tongue, like a runaway (?) donkey, does not turn back. My mouth, I give you hot soup: may you &X;&X;. From fish whose bones have been picked out, you, my mouth, &X;&X; you devour everything.

body.head: UET 6/2 255
body.p: cf. 6.1.03.134 A man's god is a man's shepherd. The god will not desert him. A shepherd should not &X;&X;. A man's god provides him with something to eat and water to drink.

body.head: UET 6/2 322
body.p: cf. 6.1.03.177, 6.2.2: MDP 27 89 From the mouth &X;&X; from the mouth &X;&X;. Whatever comes from his mouth will not be put in his hand.

body.head: UET 6/2 287
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.38 The horse, after throwing off his rider, said: Were my load to be like this forever, how weak I would become!

body.head: UET 6/2 283
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.39 The donkey, after he had thrown off his packs, said: Now I can forget my burdens of former days!

body.head: UET 6/2 315
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.42 A donkey was floating in the river, and a dog watching him from dry land said: My own dear father, where are you going? When you come near, I will shed my tears on behalf of you.
cf. 6.1.02.140 In a household of several grown-up young men, &X;&X; battle fray &X;&X;

cf. 6.1.09.d4, 6.2.1: N 4248 Seg. A ll. 8-13, 6.2.1: Ni 9824 Seg. B ll. 3-5 Run! &X;&X; the king &X;&X;. Because of silver, because of gold, because of the money chest, because of the &X;&X; chest, I am finished!

body.head: UET 6/2 236
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.44 Make the donkey sit like this! I am making it lift its shrivelled penis!

body.head: UET 6/2 234
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.46 Using a donkey in place of a sheep will not allow you to recognise any omens.

body.head: UET 6/2 212
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.55 The lion had caught a helpless goat: Let me go! I will give you my fellow ewe in return! If I am to let you go, tell me your name! The goat answered the lion: You do not know my name? '&X;&X;' is my name! When he came to the fold, he shouted: &X;&X; my &X;&X;. She answered him from the other side: &X;&X;. As for sheep, none live here!

body.head: UET 6/2 211
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.57 A lion caught a wild boar. He roared: Your flesh has not yet filled my mouth, but your squeals have deafened my ears!

body.head: UET 6/2 208
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.59 O lion, your allies in the reedbeds are numerous.
cf. 6.1.05.60 In the reedbeds the lion does not eat his acquaintance.

body.head: UET 6/2 264
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.78 A dog said to his master: If my pleasure is of no importance to you, then my loss should not be either!

body.head: UET 6/2 231
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.79 The dog does not let &X;&X; sit down in &X;&X; house.
cf. 6.1.05.80 The dog &X;&X;.

body.head: UET 6/2 225
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.81 The dog understands: Take it! It does not understand: Put it down!

body.head: UET 6/2 228
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.85 The dog which &X;&X; sheep-fat -- dog is indeed its name.

body.head: UET 6/2 223
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.97 A dog which is played with turns into a puppy.

body.head: UET 6/2 324
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.98 He cried out like a rabid dog; its reward was having its skin flayed.

body.head: UET 6/2 309
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.101 You behave like a rabid dog stretching into the river (?), guzzling water.

body.head: UET 6/2 224
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.106, 6.2.2: MDP 27 82 Don't start a fight with a dog. Will that dog not bite you?

body.head: UET 6/2 222
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.107 When a dog snarls, throw a morsel into his mouth.

body.head: UET 6/2 230
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.115 It is a dog's lot to collect bones.
cf. 6.1.05.116 A dog was going to a party. After he had seen the bones, he went away. Where I am going, I will be eating more than this, he said.

body.head: UET 6/2 232
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.120 Biting the workmen like a whelping bitch.

body.head: UET 6/2 313
body.p: cf. 6.1.05.123 Thus speaks the dog to the pups: You are mottled, you jump around -- you are my dear children.

body.head: UET 6/2 275
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.a4 A pig takes away as for himself, so for his owner.

body.head: UET 6/2 300
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.a5 Like a pig spattered with mud.
cf. 6.1.08.a6 A pig picks up morsels of bread.

body.head: UET 6/2 240
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.b4-5 A goat is the gift of a large kid, the large kid which wears a beard.

body.head: UET 6/2 241
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.b14 A bear which for six months had not turned onto his side said: Were An not to bestow sleep on someone, as he does me, they would expire.

body.head: UET 6/2 294
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.b15 Like a hyena, he will not eat it unless it stinks.

body.head: UET 6/2 215
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.b23 A fox was laying down (?) a threshing floor. It did not &X;&X; on the threshing floor, but the fox did not become exhausted.

body.head: UET 6/2 218
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.b24 The fox thought about his mother's interference and said: My &X;&X; is crushed.

body.head: UET 6/2 213
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.b25 The fox dropped her young. Her twins came out.

body.head: UET 6/2 219
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.b28 A fox &X;&X; to a goat &X;&X;. On the arrival &X;&X;. If there's a dog staying on that account in your house, &X;&X; my shoes!

body.head: UET 6/2 220
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.b29 A fox went under a thorny bush. Meanwhile a dog sat at the entrance: Come out to me! but he would not come out: How can he get in from outside? -- Unless you chase me out, I will stay sitting here.

body.head: UET 6/2 217
body.p: cf. 6.1.08.b33 The fox set his mind on some treachery: I am throwing it out. I am carrying my city to the river.

body.head: UET 6/3 462
body.p: cf. 6.1.09.a6, 6.1.10.7 Strength cannot keep pace with intelligence.

body.head: UET 6/3 464
body.p: cf. 6.1.09.d2-3, 6.1.13.29, 6.1.19.e2-3 The wise one &X;&X; knowledgeable one &X;&X;. A fool who was overwhelmed by his backside stuck his hand up his backside.

body.head: UET 6/2 282 and UET 6/2 332
body.p: cf. 6.1.12.d3 Like a wild sheep up a poplar, he went up, he kept going up.

body.head: UET 6/2 305
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 330, 6.1.15.b6 Don't give the halt man a club for his arm. Enlil shall be the one to help him!

body.head: UET 6/2 330
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 305, 6.1.15.b6 Don't give the halt man a club for his arm. Enlil shall be the one to help him!

body.head: UET 6/2 281
body.p: cf. 6.1.18.8 The quick one hid, the strong one fled; the voluble one succeeded in getting into the palace.

body.head: UET 6/2 386
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 387, 6.1.19.d11 I, a slave girl, have no authority over my lady. Let me pull my husband's hair instead.

body.head: UET 6/2 387
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 386, 6.1.19.d11 The slave girl has no authority over the lady: Let me pull my husband's hair instead.

body.head: UET 6/2 325
body.p: cf. 6.1.21.c10, 6.2.5: IM 62823 Seg. B ll. 8-9 The slave girls did not take out the bala&g; drum. Inana remained seated in the village (?).
cf. 6.1.03.36, 6.2.5: IM 62823 Seg. B ll. 11-12 The voluptuous slave girl says: Let I&c;kur, &X;&X; god &X;&X; great king &X;&X; split the fertile ground like a cucumber.

body.head: UET 6/2 259
body.p: cf. 6.1.22: ll. 49-50, 6.1.26.a4, 6.2.5: UM 29-16-519 Seg. B ll. 4-5, 6.2.5: YBC 7351, 5.6.1: l. 50 A judge who despises justice, cursing with the right hand, and the chasing away of a younger son from the house of his father are abominations to Utu.

body.head: UET 6/2 250
body.p: cf. 6.1.27.9 One city does not greet another, but one person greets another person.

body.head: UET 6/3 80
body.p: &X;&X; wearing it, it is good, &X;&X;.
&X;&X; a daughter-in-law &X;&X; the position of being my father-in-law &X;&X; bought by a wealthy man.

cf. UET 6/2 244, 6.1.02.c13-14, 6.2.2: MDP 27 206 The irsa&g; bird's voice is the glory of the gardens. The frog's voice is the glory of the marsh waters. The francolin's voice is the glory of the fields.
&X;&X; will be insulted &X;&X; bound by insults.
&X;&X; the gods are three. So it is said, so let it be!
&X;&X; mankind &X;&X; without &X;&X;
&X;&X; troubled &X;&X; strike his master.
a women weaver &X;&X;.
&X;&X; not do &X;&X; equipment &X;&X; master &X;&X; submit &X;&X;.
&X;&X; may he live. Their faces are sympathetic &X;&X;.
cf. 6.1.09.a4, 6.1.10.5, 6.1.22: l. 190 The mighty man is master of the earth.
Let me tear out &X;&X;, it will not be achieved.
&X;&X; who will do it?

div1.p: cf. UET 6/2 239, UET 6/2 320, 6.1.01.09, 6.1.22: ll. 140-145 If bread is left over, the mongoose eats it. If I have bread left over, a stranger consumes it.
cf. UET 6/2 261 and UET 6/2 262, 6.1.01.23, 4.14.1: l. 144 To be wealthy and demand more is an abomination to one's god.
Because he lives as though deaf, because of you, my son is not fit to be a scribe.

body.head: UET 6/2 289
body.p: He who slanders &X;&X; for the liar -- Ninegala will crush his head &X;&X;. His good deeds aim at evil. His looks are shameless. There are fingers pointing at him from behind. Utu, the lord who loves justice, extirpates wickedness and prolongs righteousness. A heavy punishment &X;&X; slander (?) befalls him.

body.head: UET 6/2 350
body.p:
&X;&X; ascends to heaven.
When battle approaches, when war arises, the plans of the gods, beloved by the gods, are destroyed. You cause fire to devour the Land. May my god know that my hand is suited to the stylus.

body.head: UET 6/2 365
body.p:
As for me, what did my god do?
the basket and my debt, no expenditures were made for him!
A wealthy man had accumulated a fortune. I am spending it for him. That said, it was dispersed. Afterwards he could not work out what went wrong. Things change. No one knows what will happen.

body.head: UET 6/2 368
body.p: A child without sin was never born by his mother. The idea was never conceived that there was anyone who was not a sinner. Such a situation never existed.
For him who walks, the day lasts. For him who dances, the sun shines. For the hero whose strength is enormous, moonlight is given.

body.head: UET 6/2 251
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 252, 6.2.5: YBC 7344, 4.06.1: Seg. C ll. 3-16, 5.2.4: l. 9 A man without a personal god does not procure much food, does not procure even a little food. Going down to the river, he does not catch any fish. Going down to a field, he does not catch any gazelle. In important matters he is unsuccessful. When running, he does not reach his goal. Yet were his god favourable toward him, anything he might name would be provided for him.

body.head: UET 6/2 252
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 251, 6.2.5: YBC 7344, 4.06.1: Seg. C ll. 3-16, 5.2.4: l. 9 A man without a personal god does not procure much food, does not procure even a little food. Going to a river, he does not catch any fish. Going to a field, he does not catch any gazelle. He is unsuccessful in ritual preparations, he is unsuccessful in important matters. Yet were his god favourable toward him, anything he might name would be provided for him.

body.head: UET 6/2 371
body.p: cf. 4.05.1: l. 33 One should pay attention to an old man's words and one should reap the benefits.
cf. 4.05.1: l. 34 A child should behave with modesty toward his mother. He should take the older generation into consideration.
cf. UET 6/2 288 No matter how much wisdom exerts itself (?), you, fool, achieve what you need.
cf. 4.05.1: l. 32 A younger brother should honour an older brother. He should treat him with human dignity.

body.head: UET 6/2 310
body.p:
Should not intelligence, wisdom and understanding become perfect &X;&X; to the mouth &X;&X; mankind? At the place of testimony &X;&X; friendship &X;&X;
the slippery place &X;&X; the place of god &X;&X; let &X;&X; who knows what to say &X;&X; to the mouth.

body.head: UET 6/2 271
body.p: One ferryman says to another ferryman: A &X;&X; cannot cross the river by himself.

body.head: UET 6/2 328
body.p: A girl from &G;irsu &X;&X;. Her lap &X;&X; a man. Her anus was &X;&X;. Bau &X;&X; a gate &X;&X; head &X;&X;.

body.head: UET 6/3 302
body.p: A companion &X;&X; sleeping place.

body.head: UET 6/2 238
body.p: A mouse fell down from the roof beams. A mongoose approached it: Is any part of you hurt? The mouse replied: You needn't come near me. I am equal to any part of you.

body.head: UET 6/2 272
body.p: his &X;&X; not draw a boat &X;&X; his bucket &X;&X; it is good.

body.head: UET 6/2 331
body.p: Your &X;&X; were changed. Their plans were overturned, so their cult decreased. Brothers don't see their brothers. What harm did the hero do to your ways or to your heart?

body.head: UET 6/2 349
body.p: A goose spoke as follows: &X;&X; seven times &X;&X; dwelling well, one of my feet in the middle of the night.

body.head: UET 6/2 367
body.p:
cf. 6.2.5: IM 43438 Seg. B l. 4, 5.6.1: l. 184 The poor man caused all kinds of trouble for the wealthy man.
&X;&X; skin disease lasts forever; &X;&X; forever; &X;&X; skin disease lasts forever.

body.head: UET 6/2 263
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 266, 4.08.15: ll. 225-31, 5.3.2: ll. 190-191, 5.7.1: ll. 19-21 He who has silver, he who has lapis lazuli, he who has oxen and he who has sheep wait at the gate of the man who has barley.

body.head: UET 6/2 296
body.p: What is in mankind's mouth is as difficult to hide as a wall. The boy who grew up in your town &X;&X; on you -- don't let your mouth accuse him; don't slander him; don't encourage violent retaliation against yourself.

body.head: UET 6/2 308
body.p: The little mouse spoke as follows to his mother: As I came out, nobody saw me. His mother answered him: Anyone who saw you will carry you off!

body.head: UET 6/2 380
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 381 Although I spoke, what did I gain? Although I spoke, what did it add? I covered up for myself, but what success did it bring me?

body.head: UET 6/3 378
body.p: &X;&X; erection &X;&X; Sumerian &X;&X; forehead &X;&X; kneading dough &X;&X;

body.head: UET 6/3 455
body.p: &X;&X; sunset &X;&X; basket &X;&X;.
&X;&X; true heart &X;&X; single &X;&X;.

body.head: UET 6/2 227
body.p: A dog sitting in a garden, a dog &X;&X; growing &X;&X; a dog &X;&X; demon of heaven and earth.

body.head: UET 6/2 229
body.p: A dog &X;&X;

body.head: UET 6/2 242
body.p: Let the wolf eat. &X;&X; may it get eye disease. No matter how small the dog is, you will make it grow.

body.head: UET 6/2 247
body.p: cf. 6.2.1: Ni 5327 The &X;&X; bird &X;&X; malt on the town square &X;&X; got bigger.

body.head: UET 6/2 254
body.p: Should someone clever not act cleverly, then I &X;&X;; man's intelligence comes from god.

body.head: UET 6/2 277
body.p: For your Let me work a bed has been &X;&X;. For a Let me bake! Let me bake! the owner of the oven has come home.

body.head: UET 6/2 295
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 278, UET 6/2 318 He who can say Let him hurry, let him run, let him be strong, and he will carry it! is a lucky man.

body.head: UET 6/2 299
body.p: A man who does not value his god is thrown out in the desert; his body is not buried and his heir does not provide his ghost with drinking water through a libation pipe.

body.head: UET 6/2 307
body.p: The axe belongs to the carpenter, the stone belongs to the smith, the good &X;&X; belongs to the brewer.

body.head: UET 6/2 318
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 278, UET 6/2 295 Because he always went, because he always ran, He carried away. He carried away! is the name assigned to him. A fool.

body.head: UET 6/2 321
body.p: A slave girl should not &X;&X; a slave girl. &X;&X; whatever &X;&X;

body.head: UET 6/2 326
body.p: Pleasure is created. Sins are absolved. Life is rejuvenated.

body.head: UET 6/2 338
body.p: &X;&X; born &X;&X; the deities carry torches.

body.head: UET 6/2 381
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 380 Although I spoke, what did I gain? Although I spoke, what did it add? I covered up for myself, but what success did it bring me?

body.head: UET 6/3 458
body.p: &X;&X; bird rejoices &X;&X; bird &X;&X; not &X;&X; its call &X;&X; bird &X;&X;.

body.head: U.15084 (UET 6/3 p. 84)
body.p: &X;&X; following it &X;&X; belongs to the palace.

body.head: UET 6/2 233
body.p: O mule, do you know your sire, and do you know your mother?

body.head: UET 6/2 237
body.p: Let the snake find its deep hole, the scorpion its crevice, and the hyena its exit.

body.head: UET 6/2 243
body.p: The wolf circles around it, the lion just picks it up.

body.head: UET 6/2 245
body.p: A francolin (?) keeps changing, from the rushes to the rushes.

body.head: UET 6/2 246
body.p: A francolin gave birth to fifty young. A rook tried to rise up, but could not move its wings.

body.head: UET 6/2 248
body.p: Like a raven, when something is thrown in front of your mouth you watch your own shadow.

body.head: UET 6/2 257
body.p: Let just men be born in good health, and let their lives last long.

body.head: UET 6/2 258
body.p: The just man's life lasts long. Life is the gift awarded for it.

body.head: UET 6/2 266
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 263, 4.08.15: ll. 225-31, 5.3.2: ll. 190-191, 5.7.1: ll. 19-21 He who has silver, he who has lapis lazuli, he who has oxen and he who has sheep wait at the gate of the man who has barley.

body.head: UET 6/2 270
body.p: The dog gives nothing towards the ferryboat, and yet it claps its hand for the ferryboat.

body.head: UET 6/2 274
body.p: cf. 5.3.3: l. 162 When the young scribe is absent, it is a bad thing. No rushes are torn up to make his bedding.

body.head: UET 6/2 276
body.p: Brotherhood is founded on the words of a quarrel. At the witness box, friendship becomes known.

body.head: UET 6/2 278
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 295, UET 6/2 318 Because I was always walking, because I always ran, He carried away, he carried away! is what they called me.

body.head: UET 6/2 279
body.p: A home-born slave was treated with contempt, so he wept. He had chaff in his hands, so he bared his teeth in anger.

body.head: UET 6/2 280
body.p: &X;&X; Inana &X;&X; builds a house for her &X;&X;.

body.head: UET 6/2 285
body.p: A small mouse was caught by a man: I (?) am fleeing from evil, it said.

body.head: UET 6/2 286
body.p: If I insult, I am insulted. Even if I don't treat someone with contempt, I am still treated with contempt.

body.head: UET 6/2 288
body.p: cf. UET 6/2 371 ll. 5-6 No matter how much wisdom exerts itself (?), the fool achieves what he needs.

body.head: UET 6/2 297
body.p: By following craftiness, one learns how to be crafty. By following wisdom, one learns how to be wise.

body.head: UET 6/2 304
body.p: Earth is greater than heaven. Who can destroy it?
A god's &X;&X; is founded on stone.

body.head: UET 6/2 314
body.p: To the trustworthy man belongs a divine voice (?). The barge on the river and the chariot on the road come to him.

body.head: UET 6/2 316
body.p: A woman &X;&X; womb (?): A figure is growing as tall as the grass.

body.head: UET 6/2 319
body.p: A ghost who had died said: You shouldn't carry oil.

body.head: UET 6/2 323
body.p: Like a sweet voice &X;&X;.

body.head: UET 6/2 327
body.p: One should not &X;&X; someone who &X;&X;; one should greet someone who says something.

body.head: UET 6/2 385
body.p: Your outhouse is like your &X;&X;, like your canal, like your dykes. Of what importance is it to you as a scribe?

body.head: U.8814 (UET 6/3 p. 84)
body.p: Value -- anything of mine that is hired.

body.head: UET 6/2 226
body.p: The stupidest of all shameless men.

body.head: UET 6/2 235
body.p: The overstuffed donkey must carry the straw on its neck.

body.head: UET 6/2 249
body.p: Like a raven, you have your eyes on enormous quantities of malt.

body.head: UET 6/2 253
body.p: A man without a god -- for a strong man it is no loss.

body.head: UET 6/2 256
body.p: The expenses (?) of those who neglect justice are numerous.

body.head: UET 6/2 298
body.p: Adding an inheritance share to an inheritance share is an abomination to Utu.

body.head: UET 6/2 312
body.p: When &X;&X; answers &X;&X;, it is a good omen from heaven.
